24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything27:T1f49,<entryFree id="n3658" key="بَانَ" type="main">

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بأن</orth>

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">آن</orth>
                  </form>, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>,] inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنُونَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بُيُونٌ</foreign> (M, Mgh, K) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign>, (M, K,) <hi rend="ital">It</hi> (<hi rend="ital">a thing</hi>) <hi rend="ital">became separated, severed, disunited,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut off,</hi> (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) <foreign lang="ar">عَنِ الشَّىْءِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">from the thing.</hi> (Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَتْ</foreign>, (M, K,) or <foreign lang="ar">بَانَتْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِالطَّلَاقِ</foreign>, (Msb,) <hi rend="ital">She</hi> (a wife) <hi rend="ital">became separated by divorce,</hi> (M, Msb, K,) <foreign lang="ar">عَنِ الرَّجُلِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">from the man.</hi> (M, K.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَتٌ</foreign> said of a girl, [<hi rend="ital">She became separated from her parents by marriage;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">she married:</hi> (ISh, T:) as though she became at a distance from the house of her father. (ISh, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ</foreign>, (M,) or <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ بِمَالٍ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>, (T,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بُيُونٌ</foreign> (T, M) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign>, (M,) <hi rend="ital">He became separated from his father,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mother,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">both, by property</hi> [<hi rend="ital">which he received from him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">her,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">them,</hi>] (AZ, T, M,) <hi rend="ital">to be his alone:</hi> (AZ, T:) and ElFárisee states, on the authority of AZ, that one] <pb n="286"/> says also, <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ عَنْهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَانَهُ</foreign> [the former app. meaning <hi rend="ital">he became separated thus from him,</hi> i. e., from his father; and the latter being syn. with <foreign lang="ar">أَبَانَهُ</foreign>, q. v.]. (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ الخَلِيطُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنُونَةٌ</foreign>, [<hi rend="ital">The partner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">copartner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sharer,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">became separated from the person,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">persons, with whom he had been associated.</hi>] (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَتْ يَدُ النَّاقَةِ عَنْ جَنْبِهَا</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بُيُونٌ</foreign>, [<hi rend="ital">The fore leg of the she-camel became withdrawn,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">apart, from her side.</hi>] (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ</foreign>, (S, M, Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">بَانُوا</foreign>, (K,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>, (S,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنُونَةٌ</foreign>, (S, M, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">He separated himself,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it separated itself;</hi> (S; [in one copy of which it is said of a thing;]) and <hi rend="ital">they separated themselves:</hi> (K:) or <hi rend="ital">it</hi> (a tribe, M, Msb) <hi rend="ital">went, journeyed, went away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">departed;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">went, removed, retired,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">withdrew itself, to a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far away,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">far off.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ</foreign>, (T, S, M, &amp;c.,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>, (T, Msb,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</foreign>; (T, S, Mgh, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3658-1" target="ابان" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3662"/></foreign>, (T, S, M, &amp;c.,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِبَانَةٌ</foreign>; (T, Msb;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3658-2" target="بيّن" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3659"/></foreign>, (T, S, M, &amp;c.,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيِينٌ</foreign>; (S;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3658-3" target="تبيّن" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3663"/></foreign>; and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3658-4" target="استبان" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3665"/></foreign>; (T, S, M, &amp;c.,) all signify the same; (T, M, Msb;) i. e. <hi rend="ital">It</hi> (a thing, T, S, M, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) <hi rend="ital">was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">distinct, as though separate from others;</hi> and thus,] <hi rend="ital">apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous:</hi> (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and <hi rend="ital">it was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, known.</hi> (K.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ الحَقُّ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The truth became apparent,</hi> &amp;c.; or <hi rend="ital">known</hi>]; as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3658-5" target="ابان" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3662"/></foreign>. (T.) And <quote>
                     <L><foreign lang="ar">قَدْ <ref cref="n3658-6" target="بَيَّنَ" n="6" type="5" subtype="TFSO" lang="ar"/>الصُّبْحُ لِذِى عَيْنَيْنِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The dawn has become apparent to him who has two eyes:</hi> a prov.: (S, M:) applied to a thing that becomes altogether apparent, or manifest. (Har p. 542.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 257], <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ <ref cref="n3658-7" target="تَبَيَّنَ" n="7" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الرُّشْدُ مِنَ الغَىِّ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The right belief hath become distinguished from error</hi>]. (TA.) And the lawyers, correctly, use the phrase, <foreign lang="ar">كَصَوْتٍ لَا  <ref cref="n3658-8" target="يَسْتَبِينُ" n="8" type="6" subtype="FTFSO" lang="ar"/> مِنْهُ حُرُوفٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Like a sound whereof letters are not distinguishable</hi>]. (Mgh.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [It seems to be indicated in the TA that <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنُونَةٌ</foreign>, also signifies <hi rend="ital">It was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, united,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">connected;</hi> thus having two contr. meanings; but I have not found the verb used in this sense, though <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign> signifies both disunion and union.]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَانَهُ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبِينُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">بَانَهُ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَبُونُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">بَوْنٌ</foreign>, in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>.       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  See also 2, in two places.    </entryFree>28:T2404,<entryFree id="n3659" key="بيّن" type="main">

                     <itype>2</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بيّن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بينن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ين</orth>
                  </form>, intrans., inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيِينٌ</foreign>: see 1, in two places.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  You say also, <foreign lang="ar">بيّن الشَّجَرُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The trees,</hi> (K,) <hi rend="ital">or the leaves of the trees,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">appeared, when beginning to grow forth.</hi> (K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">بيّن القَرْنُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The horn came forth.</hi> (K, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بيّن بِنْتَهُ</foreign>: see 4.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بيّنهُ</foreign>, (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيِينٌ</foreign> (T, S) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-1" target="تِبْيَانٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3678"/></foreign> (T, S, * K *) and <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيَانٌ</foreign>; (K;) the second of which three is an anomalous inf. n., (T, S, K,) for by rule it should be of the measure <foreign lang="ar">تَفْعَالٌ</foreign>; (T, S;) but <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيَانٌ</foreign> is not known except accord. to the opinion of those who allow the authority of analogy, which opinion is outweighed by the contrary; (TA;) and <foreign lang="ar">تِبْيَانٌ</foreign> is the only inf. n. of its measure except <foreign lang="ar">تِلْقَآءٌ</foreign>, (T, S,) accord. to the generality of the leading authorities; but some add <foreign lang="ar">تِمْثَالٌ</foreign>, as inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">مَثَّلَ</foreign>; and El-Hareeree adds to these two, in the Durrah, <foreign lang="ar">تِنْضَالٌ</foreign>, as inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">نَاضَلَهُ</foreign>; and Esh-Shiháb adds, in the Expos. of the Durrah, <foreign lang="ar">تِشْرَابٌ</foreign>, as inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">شَرِبَ الخَمْرَ</foreign>; asserting <foreign lang="ar">تَشْرَابٌ</foreign> also to have been heard, agreeably with analogy; [and to these may be added <foreign lang="ar">تَبْكَآءٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تِمْشَآءٌ</foreign>, and perhaps some other instances of the same kind;] but some disallow <foreign lang="ar">تِفْعَالٌ</foreign> altogether as the measure of an inf. n., saying that the words transmitted as instances thereof are simple substs. used as inf. ns., like <foreign lang="ar">طَعَامٌ</foreign> in the place of <foreign lang="ar">إِطْعَامٌ</foreign>; (MF, TA;) and Sb says that <foreign lang="ar">تِبْيَانٌ</foreign> is not an inf. n.; for, where it so, it would be <foreign lang="ar">تَبْيَانٌ</foreign>; but it is, from <foreign lang="ar">بَيَّنْتُ</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">غَارَةٌ</foreign> from <foreign lang="ar">أَغَرْتُ</foreign>; (M, TA;) [<hi rend="ital">He made it distinct, as though separate from others;</hi> and thus,] <hi rend="ital">he made it</hi> (namely, a thing, T, S, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) <hi rend="ital">apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous;</hi> (S, Msb, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-2" target="ابانهُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِبَانَةٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-3" target="تبيّنهُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3658"/></foreign>; (S, * Msb, K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-4" target="استبانهُ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (Mgh, Msb, K:) [<foreign lang="ar">بيّنهُ</foreign> is the most common in this sense: and often signifies <hi rend="ital">he explained it:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">he proved it:</hi>] and ↓ all these verbs signify also <hi rend="ital">he made it known; he notified it:</hi> (K:) or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-5" target="اِسْتَبَنْتُهُ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) <hi rend="ital">I knew it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became acquainted with it,</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">distinguished it,</hi>] (S, Mgh,) <hi rend="ital">clearly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plainly;</hi> (Mgh;) and so   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-6" target="تَبَيَّنْتُهُ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, * Mgh;) [and <foreign lang="ar">بَيَّنْتُهُ</foreign>, as appears from an ex. in what follows, from a verse of En-Nábighah:]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-7" target="بِنْتُهُ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-8" target="أَبَنْتُهُ" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-9" target="اِسْتَبَنْتُهُ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَيَّنْتُهُ</foreign> all signify the same as   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-10" target="تَبَيَّنْتُهُ" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [app. in all the senses of this verb]: (M:) or, of all these verbs,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-11" target="بَانَ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3658"/></foreign> is only intrans.: (Msb:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-12" target="اِسْتَبَنْتُهُ" n="12" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">I looked at it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">into it,</hi> (namely, a thing,) <hi rend="ital">considered it, examined it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">studied it, repeatedly, in order that it might become apparent, manifest, evident, clear,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plain, to me:</hi> (T, TA:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-13" target="تبيّنهُ" n="13" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3658"/></foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">he looked at it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">into it,</hi> (namely, an affair, or a case,) <hi rend="ital">considered it, examined it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">studied it, repeatedly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deliberately, in order to know its real state by the external signs thereof.</hi> (T.) A poet says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَمَا خِفْتُ حَتَّى بَيَّنَ الشِّرْبُ وَالأَذَى</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>  
      <foreign lang="ar">بقَانِئَةٍ أَنِّى مِنَ الحَىِّ <ref cref="n3659-14" target="أَبْيَنُ" n="14" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n3677"/></foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And I feared not until the drinking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the time of drinking, and molestation, made manifest,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plainly showed, by a deep-red</hi> (<hi rend="ital">sun</hi>), <hi rend="ital">that I was separated from the tribe:</hi> see <foreign lang="ar">قَانِئٌ</foreign>].                   <foreign lang="ar">تِبْيَانًا لِكُلِّ شَىْءٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And we have sent down to thee the Scripture to make manifest everything</hi>]; meaning, we make manifest to thee in the Scripture everything that thou and thy people require [to know] respecting matters of religion. (T.) See also <foreign lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</foreign>, in the latter half of the paragraph. En-Nábighah says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِلَّا الأَوَارِىَّ مَّا أُبَيِّنُهَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Except the places of the confinement of the beasts: with difficulty did I distinguish them</hi>]; meaning   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3659-15" target="أَتَبَيَّنُهَا" n="15" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (S.)                   <hi rend="ital">He drew away the bucket from the casing of the well, lest the latter should lacerate the former.</hi> (M.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  See also 2, in three places.          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [Hence, <foreign lang="ar">ابان</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">He spoke,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wrote, perspicuously, clearly, plainly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinctly, as to meaning;</hi> or, <hi rend="ital">with eloquence:</hi> from <foreign lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</foreign>, q. v.] And <foreign lang="ar">ابان عَلَيْهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He spoke perspicuously, clearly, plainly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinctly, and gave his testimony,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">evidence,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gave decisive information, against him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">respecting it.</hi> (TA.)                   <hi rend="ital">He does not speak plainly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinctly;</hi> lit., <hi rend="ital">does not make speech plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinct.</hi> (Ks, T in art. <foreign lang="ar">بت</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">مَا أَبْيَنَهُ</foreign>

                  <foreign lang="ar">بَيَان</foreign>!]    </entryFree>2c:T7f5,<entryFree id="n3663" key="تبيّن" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>5</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تبيّن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أبان</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بان</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تبين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تبينن</orth>
                  </form>, intrans.: see 1, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  As a trans. verb: see 2, in seven places.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence, <pb n="287"/> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الأَمْرَ</foreign> being understood,] <hi rend="ital">He sought,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sought leisurely</hi> or <hi rend="ital">repeatedly, to obtain knowledge</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of the thing</hi>], <hi rend="ital">until he knew</hi> [<hi rend="ital">it</hi>]; <hi rend="ital">he examined, scrutinized,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">investigated:</hi> (Bd in xlix. 6:) <hi rend="ital">he sought,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">endeavoured, to make the affair,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">case, manifest, and to settle it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">establish it, and was not hasty therein:</hi> (Idem in iv. 96:) or <hi rend="ital">he acted,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">proceeded, deliberately,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">leisurely, in the affair,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">case; not hastily:</hi> (Ks, TA:) or it has a signification like this: in the Kur ch. iv. v. 96 and ch. xlix. v. 6, some read <foreign lang="ar">فَتَبَيَّنُوا</foreign>, and others <foreign lang="ar">فَتَثَبَّتُوا</foreign>; and the meanings are nearly the same: <foreign lang="ar">التَّبَيُّنُ</foreign> was said by Mohammad to be from God, and <foreign lang="ar">العَجَلَةٌ</foreign> [i. e. "haste"] from the devil. (T.)    </entryFree>2d:T696,<entryFree id="n3664" key="تباينا" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>6</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تباينا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">باين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تباين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تباينا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تبايننا</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They two</hi> (namely, two men, and two copartners,) <hi rend="ital">became separated, each from the other:</hi> (M, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">they forsook,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abandoned, each other;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut each other off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ceased to speak to, each other.</hi> (K.) And <foreign lang="ar">تباينوا</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They, having been together, became separated:</hi> (Msb:) or <hi rend="ital">they forsook,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abandoned, one another;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut one another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ceased to speak to, one another.</hi> (S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence, <hi rend="ital">They two were dissimilar:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">they two</hi> (namely, words,) <hi rend="ital">were disparate;</hi> whether contraries or not: and <hi rend="ital">they two</hi> (namely, numbers,) <hi rend="ital">were incommensurable.</hi>]    </entryFree>2e:T63f7,<entryFree id="n3667" key="بَيْنٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَيْنٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بينن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ين</orth>
                  </form> has two contr. significations; (T, S, Msb;) one of which is <hi rend="ital">Separation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disunion</hi> [of companions or friends or lovers]. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) Hence, <foreign lang="ar">ذَاتُ البَيْنِ</foreign> as meaning <hi rend="ital">Enmity,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">vehement hatred:</hi> and the saying <foreign lang="ar">لِإِصْلَاحِ ذَاتِ البَيْنِ</foreign>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">For the reforming,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">amending, of the bad,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">corrupt, state subsisting between the people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">company of men;</hi> meaning <hi rend="ital">for the allaying of the discord, enmity, rancour,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vehement hatred:</hi> (Msb:) [but this has also the contr. meaning, as will be seen below: and it is explained as having a vague import; for it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">فِى إِصْلَاحِ ذَاتِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">البَيْنِ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">In the reforming,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">amending, of the circumstances subsisting between the persons to whom it relates, by frequent attention thereto.</hi> (Mgh.) [Hence also,] <foreign lang="ar">غُرَابُ البَيْنِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The raven of separation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disunion;</hi> i. e., whose appearance, or croak, is ominous of separation: said by some to be] <hi rend="ital">the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">غراب</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَبْقَعُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">in which is blackness and whiteness;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">having whiteness in the breast</hi>]; (S, K;) so described by the poet 'Antarah: (S:) or <hi rend="ital">that which is red in the beak and legs;</hi> but the black is called <foreign lang="ar">الحَاتِمُ</foreign>, because it makes [or shows] separation to be absolutely unavoidable, (Abu-1-Ghowth, S, K,) according to the assertion of the Arabs, i. e., by its croak: (Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">حتم</foreign>:) [or it is <hi rend="ital">any species of the corvus:</hi>] Hamzeh says, in his Proverbs, that this name attaches to the <foreign lang="ar">غراب</foreign> because, when the people of an abode go away to seek after herbage, it alights in the place of their tents, searching the sweepings: (Har p. 308:) but accord. to the Kádee of Granada, Aboo-'Abd-Allah Esh-Shereef, this appellation, so often occurring in poetry, properly signifies <hi rend="ital">camels that transport people from one district,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">country, to another;</hi> and he cites the following verses: <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">غَلِطَ الَّذِينَ رَأَيْتُهُمْ بِجَهَالَةٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">يَلْحَوْنَ كُلُّهُمُ غُرَابًا يَنْعَقُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">مَا الذَّنْبُ إِلَّا لِلْأَبَاعِرِ إِنَّهَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">مِمَّا يُشَتِّتُ جَمْعَهُمْ وَيُقَرِّقُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ الغُرَابَ بِيُمْنِهِ تُدْنُو النَّوَى</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">وَتُشَتِّتُ الشَّمْلَ الجَمِيعَ الأَيْنُقُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Those have erred whom I have seen, with ignorance, all of them blaming a raven croaking: the fault is not imputable save to the camels; for they are of the things that scatter and disperse their congregation: verily the place that is the object of a journey is brought near by the raven's lucky omen; but the she-camels discompose the united state</hi>]: and Ibn-'Abd-Rabbih says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">زَعَقَ الغُرَابُ فَقُلْتُ أَكْذَبُ طَائِرٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِن لَّمْ يُصَدِّقْهُ رُغَآءُ بَعِيرِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">The raven cried; and I said, A most lying bird, if the grumbling cry of a camel on the occasion of his being laden do not verify it</hi>]. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">غرب</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Distance,</hi> (S, M, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">by the space,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">interval, between two things.</hi> (Msb.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ البَلَدَيْنِ بَيْنٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Between the two countries,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">towns,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">is a distance, of space,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">interval:</hi> (Msb:) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَهُمَا بَيْنٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Between them two is a distance,</hi> with <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> when corporeal distance is meant: (Idem in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>:) or <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ بَيْنَهُمَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لَبَيْنٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Verily between them two is a distance</hi>], not otherwise, in the case of [literal] distance. (S.) And you say also, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَهُمَا بَيْنٌ بَعِيدٌ</foreign> (T in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>, S, M *) and <foreign lang="ar">بَوْنٌ بَعِيدٌ</foreign> (T in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>, S, M, * Msb * in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">Between them two</hi> [meaning two men] <hi rend="ital">is a</hi> [<hi rend="ital">wide</hi>] <hi rend="ital">distance;</hi> (M;) i. e. <hi rend="ital">between their two degrees of rank</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dignity,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">between the estimations in which they are commonly held:</hi> (Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">بون</foreign>:) in this case, the latter is the more chaste. (S.) You also say, [using <foreign lang="ar">بين</foreign> to denote <hi rend="ital">An interval of time,</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">لَقِيتُهُ بُعَيْدَاتِ بَيْنٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I met him after,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a little after, an interval,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">intervals,</hi>] when you have met him after a while, and then withheld yourself from him, and then come to him. (S, M, K. See also <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدُ</foreign>.])       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Union</hi> [of companions or friends or lovers]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) the contr. of the first of the significations mentioned above in this paragraph. (T, S, Msb.) [Hence <foreign lang="ar">ذَاتُ البَيْنِ</foreign> as meaning <hi rend="ital">The state of union</hi> or <hi rend="ital">concord</hi> or <hi rend="ital">friendship</hi> or <hi rend="ital">love subsisting between a people</hi> or <hi rend="ital">between two parties;</hi> this being likewise the contr. of a signification assigned to the same expression above: whence the phrase, <foreign lang="ar">إِفْسَادُ ذَاتِ البَيْنِ</foreign> (occurring in the S and K in art. <foreign lang="ar">ابر</foreign>, and often elsewhere,) <hi rend="ital">The marring,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disturbance, of the state of union</hi> or <hi rend="ital">concord</hi> &amp;c.: and] hence the saying, <foreign lang="ar">سَعَى فُلَانٌ لِإِصْلَاحِ ذَاتِ البَيْنِ مِنْ عَشِيرَتِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Such a one laboured for the improving of the state of union</hi> or <hi rend="ital">concord</hi> &amp;c. <hi rend="ital">of his kinsfolk;</hi> but in this instance, the meaning given in the second sentence of this paragraph seems to be more appropriate]. (Ham p. 569.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ذَاتُ بَيْنِهِمْ</foreign> may also be used as meaning <hi rend="ital">The vacant space</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">سَاحَة</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">that is between their houses,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tents.</hi> (Ham p. 195.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بَيْن</foreign> is also an adverbial noun, [as such written <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign>,] (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) capable of being used as a noun absolutely: (M, K:) it relates only to that which has space, as a country; or to that which has some number, either two or more, as two men, and a company of men; and denotes [intervention in] the interval between two things, or the middle, or midst, of two things, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or the middle of a collective number: (S:) [thus it signifies <hi rend="ital">Between,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">amidst,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">among:</hi>] its meaning is [therefore] vague, not apparent unless it is prefixed to two or more [words, or to a word signifying two or more], or to what supplies the place of such a complement: (Msb:) it must necessarily be prefixed, and may not be otherwise than in the manners just explained: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it may not be prefixed to any noun but such as denotes more than one, or to a noun that has another conjoined to it by <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign>, (M,) not by any other conjunction, (M, Msb,) acc0ord. to the usage commonly obtaining. (Msb.) You say <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ الرَّجُلَيْنِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Between the two men</hi>]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">المَالُ بَيْنَ القَوْمِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The property is between the company of men</hi>]: (M, Msb, Er-Rághib: *) and <foreign lang="ar">المَالُ بَيْنَ زَيْدٍ وَعَمْرٍو</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The property is between Zeyd and 'Amr</hi>]: and <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنِى وَبَيْنَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, is between me and him</hi>]: (M:) and <foreign lang="ar">جَلَسْتُ بَيْنَ القَوْمِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I sat in the middle of</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">amidst</hi> or <hi rend="ital">among</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the company of men:</hi> (S, K:) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَكُمَا البَعِيرَ فَخُذَاهُ</foreign>, with <foreign lang="ar">البعير</foreign> in the accus. case, [See <hi rend="ital">between you two the camel, therefore take him</hi>], a saying heard by Ks: (Lin art. <foreign lang="ar">عند</foreign>:) and <foreign lang="ar">فَسَدَ مَا بَيْنَهُمْ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The state subsisting among them became bad,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">marred,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disturbed</hi>]: (S and K in art. <foreign lang="ar">ميط</foreign>:) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ الأَيَّامِ</foreign> (M and K in art. <foreign lang="ar">ندر</foreign>) and <foreign lang="ar">فِيمَا بَيْنَ الأَيَّامِ</foreign> (S and Msb in that art.) [<hi rend="ital">In,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">during, the space of</hi> (<hi rend="ital">several</hi>) <hi rend="ital">days</hi>]: and <foreign lang="ar">عَوَانٌ بَيْنَ ذٰلِكَ</foreign>, in the Kur [ii. 63], is an ex. of its being prefixed to a single word supplying the place of more than one; (Mgh, Msb;) the meaning being, <hi rend="ital">Of middle age, between that</hi> which has been mentioned; namely, the <foreign lang="ar">فَارِض</foreign> and the <foreign lang="ar">بِكْر</foreign>. (Bd.) Some allow that two words to the former of which <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> is prefixed may be connected by <foreign lang="ar">فَ</foreign>, citing as an evidence the phrase used by Imra-el-Keys, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ الدَّخُولِ فَحَوْمَلِ</foreign> [as though meaning <hi rend="ital">Between Ed-Dakhool and Howmal</hi>]: but to this it has been replied that <foreign lang="ar">الدخول</foreign> is a name applying to several places; so that the phrase [means <hi rend="ital">amidst Ed-Dakhool</hi> &amp;c., and] is similar to the saying, <foreign lang="ar">المَالُ بَيْنَ القَوْمِ</foreign> [mentioned above, or <foreign lang="ar">جَلَسْتُ بَيْنَ القَوْمِ</foreign>, also mentioned above]. (Msb.) [You say also, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ أَظْهُرِهِمْ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ ظَهْرَيْهِمْ</foreign> &amp;c., meaning <hi rend="ital">In the midst of them.</hi> (See art. <foreign lang="ar">ظهر</foreign>.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِمْ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">Before him,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">before them.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَيْن</foreign> is also often used absolutely as a noun: thus it is in the Kur lxxxvi. 7, <foreign lang="ar">يَخْرُجُ مِنْ بَيْنِ الصُّلْبِ وَالتَّرَائِبِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Coming</hi> 
                  <pb n="288"/> 
                  <hi rend="ital">forth from between,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">amidst, the spine and the breast-bones:</hi> and in xxxvi. 8 of the same, <foreign lang="ar">وَجَعَلْنَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ بَيْنِ أَيْديهِمْ سَدًّا</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">And we have placed before them</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">between their hands</hi>) <hi rend="ital">a barrier.</hi>] It is said in the Kur [vi. 94], <foreign lang="ar">لَقَدْ تَقَطَّعَ بَيْنُكُمْ</foreign>, as some read; or <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَكُمْ</foreign>, as others: (T, S, M:) the former means <hi rend="ital">Verily your union hath become dissevered:</hi> (AA, T, S, M:) the latter, <hi rend="ital">that which was between you;</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَا بَيْنَكُمْ</foreign>, Ibn-Mes'ood, T, S, or <foreign lang="ar">ٱلَّذِى كَانَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَكُمْ</foreign>, IAar, T;) or <hi rend="ital">the state wherein ye were, in respect of partnership among you:</hi> (Zj, T:) or <hi rend="ital">the state of circumstances,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the bond,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the love,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affection,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">formerly subsisting</hi>] <hi rend="ital">among you,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">between you;</hi> or, accord. to Akh, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَكُمْ</foreign>, though in the accus. case as to the letter, is in the nom. case as to the place, by reason of the verb, and the adverbial termination is retained only because the word is commonly used as an adv. n.: (M:) AHát disapproved of the latter reading; but wrongly, because what is suppressed accord. to this reading is implied by what precedes in the same verse. (T.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [It is often used as a partitive, or distributive; as also <foreign lang="ar">مَا بَيْنَ</foreign>: for ex.,] you say, <foreign lang="ar">هُمْ بَيْنَ حَاذِفٍ وَقَاذِفٍ</foreign>, (S and TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">قذف</foreign>,) or <foreign lang="ar">هُمْ مَا بَيْنَ حَاذفٍ وقاذفٍ</foreign>, (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">حذف</foreign>,) i. e. [<hi rend="ital">They are partly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in part,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">beating with the staff,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stick, and</hi> [<hi rend="ital">partly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in part,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">pelting with stones;</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">some beating</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">and the others pelting</hi> &amp;c.] (S and TA, both in art. <foreign lang="ar">قذف</foreign>, and the latter in art. <foreign lang="ar">حذف</foreign>.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce <foreign lang="ar">خَيْطَةٌ</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">هٰذَا بَيْنَ بَيْنَ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">This</hi> (namely, a thing, S, or a commodity, Msb) <hi rend="ital">is between good and bad:</hi> (S, Msb, K:) or <hi rend="ital">of a middling,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">middle, sort:</hi> (M:) these two words being two nouns made one, and indecl., with fet-h for their terminations, (S, Msb, K,) like <foreign lang="ar">خَمْسَةَ عَشَرَ</foreign>. (Msb.) <foreign lang="ar">الهَمْزَةُ المُخَفَّفَةُ</foreign> [i. e. the hemzeh uttered lightly] is called <foreign lang="ar">هَمْزَةٌ بَيْنَ بَيْنَ</foreign>, (S, M, K, *) i. e. <hi rend="ital">A hemzeh that is between the hemzeh and the soft letter whence is its vowel;</hi> (S, M;) or <foreign lang="ar">هَمْزَةُ بَيْنِ بَيْنٍ</foreign>, the first <foreign lang="ar">بين</foreign> with kesreh but without tenween, and the second with tenween, (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab,) [i. e. <hi rend="ital">the hemzeh</hi> &amp;c.:] if it is with fet-h, it is between the hemzeh and the alif, as in <foreign lang="ar">سَاَلَ</foreign>, (S, M,) for <foreign lang="ar">سَأَلَ</foreign>; (M;) if with kesr, it is between the hemzeh and the yé, as in <foreign lang="ar">سَيِمَ</foreign>, (S, M,) for <foreign lang="ar">سَئِمَ</foreign>; (M;) and if with damm, it is between the hemzeh and the wáw, as in <foreign lang="ar">لَوُمَ</foreign>, (S, M,) for <foreign lang="ar">لَؤُمَ</foreign>: (M:) it is never at the beginning of a word, because of its nearness, by reason of feebleness, to the letter that is quiescent, (S, M,) though, notwithstanding this, it is really movent: (S:) it is thus called because it is weak, (Sb, S, M,) not having the power of the hemzeh uttered with its proper sound, nor the clearness of the letter whence is its vowel. (M.) 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">تَحْمِى حَقِيقَتَنَا وَبَعْ ضُ القَوْمِ يَسْقُطُ بَيْنَ بَيْنَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> i. e. [<hi rend="ital">Thou defendest what we ought to defend,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">our banner,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">standard, while some of the people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">company of men,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">fall, one after another, in a state of weakness, not regarded as of any account:</hi> (S:) or it is as though he said, <hi rend="ital">between these and these;</hi> like a man who enters between two parties in some affair, and falls, or slips, or commits a mistake, and is not honourably mentioned in relation to it: so says Seer: (IB, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">between entering into fight and holding back from it;</hi> as when one says, Such a one puts forward a foot, and puts back another. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>    
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3667-1" target="بَيْنَا" n="1" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n3668"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3667-2" target="بَيْنَمَا" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3669"/></foreign> are of the number of inceptive <foreign lang="ar">حُرُوف</foreign>: (M, K:) this is clear if by <foreign lang="ar">حروف</foreign> is meant "words:" that they have become particles, no one says: they are still adv. ns.: (MF, TA:) the former is <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> with its [final] fet-hah rendered full in sound; and hence the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign>; (Mughnee in the section next after that of <foreign lang="ar">وا</foreign>, and K;) [i. e.,] it is of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَعْلَى</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">فَعْلَا</foreign>] from <foreign lang="ar">البَيْن</foreign>, the [final] fet-hah being rendered full in sound, and so becoming <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign>; and the latter is <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> with <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> [restrictive of its government] added to it; and both have the same meaning [of <hi rend="ital">While,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">whilst</hi>]: (S:) or the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> in the former is the restrictive <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign>; or, as some say, it is a portion of the restrictive <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign> [in the latter]: (Mughnee ubi suprà:) and these do not exclude <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> from the category of nouns, but only cut it off from being prefixed to another noun: (MF, TA:) they are substitutes for that to which <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> would otherwise be prefixed: (Mgh:) some say that these two words are adv. ns. of time, denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; and they are prefixed to a proposition consisting of a verb and an agent, or an inchoative and enunciative; so that they require a complement to complete the meaning. (TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">نَحْنُ كَذٰلِكَ إِذْ حَدَثَ كَذَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">While we were in such a state as that, lo,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">there,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">then, such a thing happened,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">came to pass</hi>]: (M, Mgh, * K: *) and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَمَا نَحْنُ كَذَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">While we were thus</hi>]: (Mgh:) and <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَا نَحْنُ نَرْقُبُهُ أَتَانَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">While we were looking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">waiting, for him, he came to us</hi>]; (S, M;) a saying of a poet, cited by Sb; (M;) the phrase being elliptical; (S, M;) meaning <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ أَوْقَاتِ نَحْنُ نَرْقُبُهُ</foreign>, (M,) i. e., <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَوْقَاتِ رِقْبَتِنَا إِيَّاهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">between the times of our looking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">waiting, for him</hi>]. (S, M.) As used to put nouns following <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَا</foreign> in the gen. case when <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign> might properly supply its place; as in the saying (of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, which he thus recited, with kesr, S), <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَا تَعَنُّقِهِ الكُمَاةَ وَرَوْغِهِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">يَوْمًا أُتِيحَ لَهُ جَرِىْءٌ سَلْفَعُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Amid his embracing the courageous armed men, and his guileful eluding, one day a bold, daring man was appointed for him,</hi> to slay him]: (S, K:) in [some copies of] the K, <foreign lang="ar">تَعَنُّفِهِ</foreign>; but in the Deewán [of the Hudhalees], <foreign lang="ar">تعنّقه</foreign>: [in the Mughnee, ubi suprà, <foreign lang="ar">تَعَانُقِهِ</foreign>:] the meaning is <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ تَعَانُقِهِ</foreign>; the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> being added to give fulness to the sound of the [final] vowel: (TA:) As used to say that the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> is here redundant: (Skr, TA:) others put the nouns following both <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَمَا</foreign> in the nom. case, as the inchoative and enunciative. (Skr, S, K.) Mbr says that when the noun following <foreign lang="ar">بينا</foreign> is a real subst., it is put in the nom. case as an inchoative; but when it is an inf. n., or a noun of the inf. kind, it is put in the gen., and <foreign lang="ar">بينا</foreign> in this instance has the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَ</foreign>: and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says the like, but some persons of chaste speech treat the latter kind of noun like the former: after <foreign lang="ar">بينما</foreign>, however, each kind of noun must be in the nom. case. (AA, T.) [See an ex. in a verse cited towards the end of art. <foreign lang="ar">اذ</foreign>.]    </entryFree>2f:T466,<entryFree id="n3670" key="بِينٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بِينٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بينن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ين</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A separation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">division,</hi> (T, M, K,) <hi rend="ital">between two things,</hi> (T,) or <hi rend="ital">between two lands;</hi> (M, K;) <hi rend="ital">as when there is a rugged place, with sands near it, and between the two is a tract neither rugged nor plain:</hi> (T:) <hi rend="ital">an elevation in rugged ground:</hi> (M, K:) the <hi rend="ital">extent to which the eye reaches,</hi> (T, M, K,) of a road, (T,) or of land: (M:) <hi rend="ital">a piece of land extending as far as the eye reaches:</hi> (T, S:) and <hi rend="ital">a region, tract,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quarter:</hi> (AA, T, M, K:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">بُيُونٌ</foreign>. (S, TA.)    </entryFree>30:T18a8,<entryFree id="n3671" key="بَيَانٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بيان</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">يان</orth>
                  </form> is originally the inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">بَانَ</foreign> as syn. with <foreign lang="ar">تَبَيَّنَ</foreign>, and so signifies The <hi rend="ital">being</hi> [<hi rend="ital">distinct</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">apparent</hi> &amp;c.; (Kull;) or it is a subst. in this sense: (Msb:) or a subst. from <foreign lang="ar">بَيَّنَ</foreign>, [and so signifies the <hi rend="ital">making distinct</hi> or <hi rend="ital">apparent</hi> &amp;c.,] being like <foreign lang="ar">سَلَامٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">كَلَامٌ</foreign> from <foreign lang="ar">سَلَّمَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">كَلَّمَ</foreign>. (Kull.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Hence, conventionally, (Kull,) The <hi rend="ital">means by which one makes</hi> a thing [<hi rend="ital">distinct,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous:</hi> (S, Er-Rághib, TA, Kull:) this is of two kinds: one is [<hi rend="ital">a circumstantial indication</hi> or <hi rend="ital">evidence;</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">a thing indicating,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">giving evidence of, a circumstance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">state, that is a result,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an effect, of a quality</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an attribute:</hi> the other is <hi rend="ital">a verbal indication</hi> or <hi rend="ital">evidence, either spoken or written:</hi> [see also <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنَةٌ</foreign>:] it is also applied to <hi rend="ital">language that discovers and shows the meaning that is intended:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">an explanation of confused and vague language:</hi> (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the <hi rend="ital">eduction</hi> of a thing <hi rend="ital">from a state of dubiousness to a state of clearness:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">making the meaning apparent to the mind so that it becomes distinct from other meanings and from what might be confounded with it.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Perspicuity, clearness, distinctness, chasteness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eloquence, of speech</hi> or <hi rend="ital">language:</hi> (T, S:) or simply <hi rend="ital">perspicuity thereof:</hi> (Har p. 2:) or <hi rend="ital">perspicuity of speech with quickness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sharpness, of intellect:</hi> (M, K:) or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chaste,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eloquent, speech, declaring,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">telling plainly, what is in the mind:</hi> (Ksh, TA:) or the <hi rend="ital">showing of the intent,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">meaning, with the most eloquent expression:</hi> it is an effect of understanding, and of sharpness, or quickness, of mind, with perspicuity, or chasteness, or eloquence, of speech: (Nh, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a faculty,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">principles,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">or a science,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">whereby one knows how to express</hi> [<hi rend="ital">with perspicuity of diction</hi>] <hi rend="ital">one meaning in various forms:</hi> (Kull:) [some of the Arabs restrict the science of <foreign lang="ar">البيان</foreign> to <hi rend="ital">what concerns comparisons and tropes and metonymies;</hi> which last the Arabian rhetoricians distinguish from tropes: and some make it to include <hi rend="ital">rhetoric</hi> altogether:] Esh-Shereeshee says, in his Expos. of the Maká- mát [of El-Hareeree] that the difference between <foreign lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3671-1" target="تِبْيَانٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3678"/></foreign> is this: that the former denotes <pb n="289"/> 
                  <hi rend="ital">perspicuity of meaning;</hi> and the latter, the <hi rend="ital">making the meaning to be understood;</hi> and the former is to another person, and the latter to oneself; but sometimes the latter is used in the sense of the former: (TA:) or the former is the act of the tongue, and the latter is the act of the mind: (Har p. 2:) or the former concerns the verbal expression, and the latter concerns the meaning. (Kull.) It is said in a trad., <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ مِنَ البَيَانِ سِحْرًا</foreign> (S) or <foreign lang="ar">لَسِحْرًا</foreign> (TA) [<hi rend="ital">Verily there is a kind of eloquence that is enchantment:</hi> see this explained in art. <foreign lang="ar">سحر</foreign>]. The saying in the Kur [lv. 2 and 3], <foreign lang="ar">خَلَقَ ٱلْإِنْسَانَ عَلَّمَهُ ٱلْبَيَانَ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">He hath created the Prophet: He hath taught him the Kur-án wherein is the manifestation of everything</hi> [<hi rend="ital">needful to be known</hi>]: or <hi rend="ital">He hath created Adam,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">man</hi> as meaning all mankind: <hi rend="ital">He hath</hi> [<hi rend="ital">taught him speech, and so</hi>] <hi rend="ital">made him to discriminate, and thus to be distinguished from all</hi> [<hi rend="ital">other</hi>] <hi rend="ital">animals:</hi>(Zj, T:) or <hi rend="ital">He hath taught him that whereby he is distinguished from other animals,</hi> namely, <hi rend="ital">the declaration of what is in the mind, and the making others to understand what he has perceived,</hi> for the reception of inspiration, and the becoming acquainted with the truth, and the learning of the law. (Bd.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  It is also applied to <hi rend="ital">Verbosity, and the going deep,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">being extravagant, in speech, and affecting to be perspicuous,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chaste, therein,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eloquent, and pretending to excel others therein;</hi> or some <foreign lang="ar">بيان</foreign> is thus termed; and is blamed in a trad., as a kind of hypocrisy; as though it were a sort of self-conceit and pride. (TA.)    </entryFree>31:T466,<entryFree id="n3672" key="بِئْرٌ بَيُونٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بِئْرٌ بَيُونٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A well of which the rope does not strike against the sides, because its interior is straight:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">that is wide in the upper part, and narrow in the lower:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in which the drawer of water makes the rope to be aloof from its sides, because of its crookedness:</hi> (T:) or <hi rend="ital">deep and wide;</hi> (S, K;) <hi rend="ital">because the ropes are wide apart from its sides;</hi> (S;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3672-1" target="بَائِنَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (S, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">that is wide between the two</hi> [<hi rend="ital">opposite</hi>] <hi rend="ital">sides:</hi> (M:) pl. [regularly of the latter epithet] <foreign lang="ar">بَوَائِنُ</foreign>. (T, S.)    </entryFree>32:Td21,<entryFree id="n3673" key="بَيِّنٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَيِّنٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بين</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">بينن</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ين</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">Distinct, as though separate from others;</hi> and thus,] <hi rend="ital">apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous;</hi> (T, S, Msb, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3673-1" target="بَائِنٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3675"/></foreign> (T) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3673-2" target="مُبِينٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3680"/></foreign>: (T, S:) pl. [of mult.] <foreign lang="ar">أَبْيِنَآءُ</foreign> (S, K) and [of pauc.] <foreign lang="ar">بَيِنَةٌ</foreign>. (K.) Hence, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3673-3" target="المُبِينٌ" n="3" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الكِتَابُ</foreign> [as applied to the Kur, q. v. in xii. 1, &amp;c.,] <hi rend="ital">The clear, plain,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perspicuous, book</hi> or <hi rend="ital">writing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scripture:</hi> or, as some say, this means <hi rend="ital">the book</hi> &amp;c. <hi rend="ital">that makes manifest all that is required</hi> [<hi rend="ital">to be known</hi>]: (T:) or, <hi rend="ital">of which the goodness and the blessing are made manifest:</hi> or, <hi rend="ital">that makes manifest the truth as distinguished from falsity, and what is lawful as distinguished from what is unlawful, and that the prophetic office of Mohammad is true, and so are the narratives relating to the prophets:</hi> (Zj, T:) or, <hi rend="ital">that makes manifest the right paths as distinguished from the wrong.</hi> (M, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">كَلَامٌ بَيِّنٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eloquent, language.</hi> (T.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  A man, or thing, <hi rend="ital">bearing evidence</hi> of a quality &amp;c. that he, or it, possesses. (S and K and other Lexicons passim.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  A man (M) <hi rend="ital">perspicuous,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clear,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">distinct, in speech</hi> or <hi rend="ital">language;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chaste therein;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eloquent;</hi> (ISh, T, M, K;) <hi rend="ital">fluent, elegant, and elevated, in speech, and having little hesitation therein:</hi> (ISh, T:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَبْيِنَآءُ</foreign> (T, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">بُيَنَآءُ</foreign> and [of pauc.] <foreign lang="ar">أَبْيَانٌ</foreign>: (Lh, M, K:) the second of these pls. is anomalous: the last is formed by likening <foreign lang="ar">فَعِيلٌ</foreign> to <foreign lang="ar">فَاعِلٌ</foreign>: [for <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنٌ</foreign> is a contraction of <foreign lang="ar">بَيِينٌ</foreign>:] but the pl. most agreeable with analogy is <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنُونَ</foreign>: so says Sb. (M.)    </entryFree>33:T4c2,<entryFree id="n3674" key="بَيِّنَةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَيِّنَةٌ</orth>

                  <hi rend="ital">An evidence, an indication, a demonstration, a proof, a voucher,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an argument,</hi> (Mgh, TA,) <hi rend="ital">such as is manifest,</hi> or. <hi rend="ital">clear, whether intellectual or perceived by sense;</hi> (TA;) [originally <foreign lang="ar">بَيِينَةٌ</foreign>,] of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَعِيلَةٌ</foreign>, from <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنُونَةٌ</foreign>, [see 1, first sentence,] and <foreign lang="ar">بَيَانٌ</foreign> [q. v.]: (Mgh:) and the <hi rend="ital">testimony of a witness:</hi> pl. <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنَاتٌ</foreign>. (TA.)    </entryFree>34:T14dd,<entryFree id="n3675" key="بَائِنٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بَائِنٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">In a state of separation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disunion;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">separated, severed, disunited,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cut off;</hi> (M, * Msb;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3675-1" target="أَبْيَنُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3677"/></foreign>, occurring in a verse cited above, voce <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنَ</foreign>. [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">اِمْرَأَةٌ بَائِنٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A woman separated from her husband by divorce;</hi> (M, Msb, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3675-2" target="مُبَانَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: the former without <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>: (Msb:) like <foreign lang="ar">طَالِقٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">حَائِضٌ</foreign>: you say [to a wife] <foreign lang="ar">أَنْتِ بَائِنٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Thou art separated</hi> from me <hi rend="ital">by divorce.</hi>] (Mgh.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">طَلَاقٌ بَائِنٌ</foreign> is a tropical phrase; and so is <foreign lang="ar">طَلْقَةٌ بَائِنَةٌ</foreign>; (Mgh;) [signifying the same as] <foreign lang="ar">تَطْلِيقَةٌ بَائِنَةٌ</foreign> (S, M, Msb, K) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A divorce that is</hi> [<hi rend="ital">as it were</hi>] <hi rend="ital">cut off; i. q.</hi>   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3675-3" target="مُبَانَةٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar"/></foreign> [in the second and third of these phrases, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n3675-4" target="مُبَانٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n3679"/></foreign> in the first]: (ISk, Msb:) <foreign lang="ar">بائنة</foreign> being here used in the sense of a pass. part. n.: (S, Sgh, Msb:) or it [is a possessive epithet, and thus] means <hi rend="ital">having separation:</hi> this kind of divorce is <hi rend="ital">one in the case of which the man cannot take back the woman unless by a new contract;</hi> (TA;) <hi rend="ital">nor without her consent.</hi> (MF in art. <foreign lang="ar">بت</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">قَوْسٌ بَائِنَةٌ</foreign>, (S, M, K,) and <foreign lang="ar">بَائِنٌ</foreign>, (M, K,) <hi rend="ital">A bow that is widely separate from its string:</hi> (S, M, K:) <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَانِيَةٌ</foreign>; (S, M;) this signifying one that is so near to its string as almost to stick to it: (S:) each of these denotes what is a fault. (S, M.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">بِئْرٌ بَائِنَةٌ</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">بَيُونٌ</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">نَخْلَةٌ بَائِنَةٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">A palm-tree of which the racemes have come forth from the spathes, and of which the fruit-stalks have grown long.</hi> (AHn, M.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">البَائِنُ</foreign> also signifies <hi rend="ital">He who comes to the milch beast</hi> [meaning <hi rend="ital">the she-camel, when she is to be milked,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">from her left side;</hi> (S, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">المُعَلِّى</foreign>, he who comes to her from her right side: (S:) or the former, <hi rend="ital">he who stands on the right of the she-camel when she is milked, and holds the milking-vessel, and raises it to the milker, who stands on her left, and is called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">المُسْتَعْلِى</foreign>: (T:) two persons are engaged in milking the she-camel; one of them holds the milking-vessel on the right side, and the other milks on the left side; and the milker is called <foreign lang="ar">المُسْتَعْلِى</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">المُعَلِّى</foreign>; and the holder, <foreign lang="ar">البائن</foreign>: (M:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">بُيَّنٌ</foreign>. (T.) It is said in a prov., <foreign lang="ar">اِسْتُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">البَائِنِ أَعْرَفُ</foreign>, or, as some say, <foreign lang="ar">أَعْلَمُ</foreign>; meaning <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">He who has superintended an affair, and exercised himself diligently in the management thereof, is better acquainted with it than he who has not done this.</hi> (T. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 606.])          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">طَوِيلٌ بَائِنٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Excessively tall, far above the stature of tall men.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">بَيِّنٌ</foreign>.
